BY WILLIAM S. CLARK, MD.


Director, Medical Department
Natl Foundation-March Of Dimes


Most of my travels around the
country take me to universities,
medical schools and hospitals,
where The National Foundation
March Of Dimes sponsors re-
search projects or treatment
centers.


However, occasionally ] get TO
address the general public. Here
are the three questions most fire.
auently asked at these meetings,
where March Of Dimes volunteers
gather to learn the latest facts
about birth defects.


No. /. IL 1t true that the time
Just before birth II most impor-

rant to an unborn baby7


Every day Is important to an
unborn baby, but the most vital
time Is actually the first few
months directly after the child
Is conceived, when most women
do not even realize that they are
pregnant. 1t Is during this time
that all Of the organs Of q chil6s
body are being formed. tits dur
ing this dime that a pregnant wo-
man most Of all needs proper
diet. more rest and mild exer-
else. 1t Is during this time that
she should be under the closest
care Of her own physician or q
prenatal clinic, to be certain
that she is following the best
routine for herself and her baby.
So the answer to question No. !.
then, IL mo" for the reasons
outlined.


No. 2. Should prsxant woman
try to cut down on her smoNng7


Absolutely. However, II thar
question 10 phrased SHOULD q
pregnant woman GIVE UP smok-
ing" usually point out that
there Is no clear-cut Eyes" or
"no' which will hold true for
every woman in the country. The
difference between a cigarette
smoker and a non-cigarette smo-
ker Is far greater than simply
the cigarette between the lipes.
There are dietary difference,
differences in pers onality. diff
ferences In the degree ofnervous
tension.


On a human level, II a doctor
were to try to force a thoroughly
addicted cigarette smoker to
cease, It would, first Of all, not
work. And second, It might
create, from the mothers in
creased tension and eating prob
lens, increased hazards for the
unborn baby.


Many heavy smokers, however.
motivated in pregnancy by the
desire to protect their child, can
successfully be persuaded tenn
porarily to reduce their ciga-
rette consumption.


No. 8. What wdvice does the
National Foundation have for q
pregnant woman7


The National Foundations
March Of Dimes, now seeking
The causes and prevention Of
birth defects, stresses this ad-
vice for the nother-to-be: See
FOUR doctor early and regularly.
10 not take drugs and pills With
'ut his permission. Eat q we'll
'alanced diet. Never be x-rayed

One advantage Of re-roofing

directly over the old material,
This eliminates the expense and
mess of ripping off the old roof.
